title: What's News --  Business & Finance
text:
U.S. stocks slid, with the Dow losing 2.4% to close below 30000 for the first time since January 2021, as volatility continued to rock the market. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq fell 3.3% and 4.1%, respectively.

---

The U.S. economy is beginning to slow under the combined weight of soaring inflation and climbing interest rates, including the highest mortgage rates in more than 13 years.

---

The Bank of England raised its key interest rate by a quarter percentage point for the fifth consecutive time, but said larger moves might be needed to tame inflation.

---

Musk told Twitter employees that he wants to dramatically increase the platform's users and didn't rule out layoffs as he works to complete his $44 billion takeover.

---

Revlon filed for bankruptcy, potentially ending a decadeslong bet on the beauty-products company by Ronald Perelman.

---

Walmart is raising wages for its pharmacy technicians, a sign that large retail pharmacies continue to compete fiercely for some workers.

---

Facebook owner Meta Platforms, Twitter and other social-media platforms have agreed to abide by tougher EU standards for policing online postings.

---

An internal review at Activision didn't unearth any evidence to suggest that senior executives ignored or played down reports of sexual harassment at the videogame firm, the company said.
